citation.article-title: "Bacillus thermoantarcticus" sp. nov., from Mont Melbourne, Antarctica: a novel thermophilic species.

p.s: Description of Bacillus thermoantarcticus sp. nov.
Bacillus thermoantarcticus (ther'mo, antarcti, cus Gr. n. thermo heat; M. L. adj. antarcticus from Antarctica, referring to the habitat of isolate)
Gram-positive rods, 0.5-2.0 μm in diameter, 3.0- to 5.0-μm long.
Cells grow aerobically at temperatures ranging from 37°C to 65°C, with optimal growth at 63°C.
The pH range suitable for growth is 5.5-9.0, with optimal growth at pH 6.0.
Yeast extract, glucose, trehalose and xylose support the growth.
The DNA base ratio is 53.7 mol% G + C.
Lipids are based on ester linkages, glycolipids are absent and high amounts of iC17:0 and aiC 17:0 are present.
It produces an exopolysaccharide, exo- and endocellular α-glucosidase(s) and an exocellular xylanase.
Type strain: "Bacillus thermoantarcticus" (DSM 9572) was deposited in the German Collection of Microorganisms, Braunschweig-Stöckheim.
Isolated from the geothermal soil of Mount Melbourne, Antarctica.
